review.title: Regression and Learning to Rank Aggregation for User Engagement Evaluation
review.abstract: User engagement refers to the amount of interaction an instance (e.g., tweet, news, and forum post) achieves. Ranking the items in social media websites based on the amount of user participation in them, can be used in different applications, such as recommender systems. In this paper, we consider a tweet containing a rating for a movie as an instance and focus on ranking the instances of each user based on their engagement, i.e., the total number of retweets and favorites it will gain.

sections.heading: 3. METHODOLOGY
sections.text: In general, our idea is to extract a number of features for each tweet and then try to learn machine learning models based on the training data. We then apply the model learned for each user in test data to classify their tweets based on their engagement. In this section, we first present the features and then propose some approaches to machine learning to classify the tweets based on their engagement. We also try to aggregate the results of these different techniques to improve performance. In the following subsections, we explain our methodology in detail.

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In order to classify each user's tweets according to their engagement, we first defined several features that are divided into three different categories: user-based, film-based and tweet-based. We showed that the features are selected from all of these categories after feature selection has been carried out. Then, we used regression and methods to classify each user's tweets according to their engagement. Finally, we aggregated the results of all regression and learning to classify methods using a monitored Kemeny approach. We evaluated our methods on an extended version of the MovieTweeting dataset of the ACMRecSys Challenge 2014. Experimental results show that feature selection significantly influences performance. metadata.abstractText: User engagement refers to the amount of interaction an instance (e.g., tweet, news, and forum post) achieves. Ranking the items in social media websites based on the amount of user participation in them, can be used in different applications, such as recommender systems. In this paper, we consider a tweet containing a rating for a movie as an instance and focus on ranking the instances of each user based on their engagement, i.e., the total number of retweets and favorites it will gain. For this task, we define several features which can be extracted from the meta-data of each tweet. The features are partitioned into three categories: user-based, movie-based, and tweet-based. We show that in order to obtain good results, features from all categories should be considered. We exploit regression and learning to rank methods to rank the tweets and propose to aggregate the results of regression and learning to rank methods to achieve better performance. We have run our experiments on an extended version of MovieTweeting dataset provided by ACM RecSys Challenge 2014. The results show that learning to rank approach outperforms most of the regression models and the combination can improve the performance significantly.
